div.p: Swing Editor: I have just finished reading the November 13th Racktalk column. This fuss over the jazz issue has been very amusing, very interesting, and also very idiotic. Although I am a Dixie­ land fan (“fig” to the modern cats), I am not trying to sell my interests to anyone. I would, however, like to clear up loose and sloppy ends.

Modern jazz is definitely a progressive form of music. It is directly connected to commer­ cialism, big bands, arrange­ ments and the public. The par­ ticipants in a modern jazz band play to and for the people. Their style of music is high­ strung, fast and loud. Its uniqueness is the installment of new sounds and an inexhaust­ ible supply of new songs, all of which sound exactly the same to anybody other than the “gates” who dig the stuff.

On the other hand, Dixieland is a backstreet sort of jazz. The musicians are highly artistic and do not rely on orchestra­ tions or arrangements. Nor do they have or need a director. If anyone wishes to “sit ip” and listen, they «re welcome. The characteristics of a jazz band of this sort are: smallness (usu­ ally limited to six players), an inter-play of slow blues, rag­ time, and fast, bouncy tunes, and complete independence to use solos and adlibs as the oppor­ tunities arise for such.

Which music is the oldest? Dixieland by about 30 years. Progressive jazz was introduced bv the swing bands of the 19305. Which music is the best? Like every other debatable question in the world, that is strictly up to the individual. I concede any favoritism to the Progressives. After all they want it the most. I also suggest the matter be dropped. Richard Fdererick.

Sway Editor: Although I don’t wish to per­ petuate the dixieland vsv Pro gressive Jazz hassle brewing on campus I feel, as do many others, that such infantile state­ ments as those printed in recent issues of the DRK deserve some' comment.

In the first place, it is exactly such obnoxious remarks as those made by pseudo-hip progres­ sivites that taint the whole realm of Progressive jazz. Any real jazz fan deserving of re­ cognition would never be so dogmatic or un-enlightened as to scorn a musical movement which has contributed so greatly to the development of Progressive jazz as has Dixieland.

Thirdly, knowing many of the members of the Conover-Theimer “Dig Rand” personally, I’m quite sure that such representa­ tive Progressive musicians as Jack Holiday, Charley Walp, Mert Oliver, Marky Markowitz, and Joe Theimer are not at all happy about being so grossly mis-represented by a pack of high-schoolish zelots, such as those letter writers of last Fri­ day’s DRK issue. In factxthose supposedly v“cool” people would have been exceedingly embar­ rassed by the comments I re­ received when I showed their ridiculous letter to Marky and some of the other musicians. And finally, the so called “hip” language is strictly passe except for such ostentatious pseudos who would like to feel that they belong to the jazz world. Musicians, who have invented and used their own specialized universal terms and sayings for over 30 years, are now appalled by the commer­ cialization and cliqueism which has become an adolescent-like fad, and they have largely abandoned the useage of what is rightfully their own. See you around, Ted Smith, MS Senior
